author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘True Detective’ Season 4, Episode 3 Recap: Toxicity
description: Danvers and Navarro both must face some cold realities about who and what they represent in a community being poisoned by its biggest employer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: Former Contractor Who Leaked Trump’s Tax Returns Sentenced to 5 Years in Prison
description: Prosecutors accused Charles Littlejohn, 38, of stealing the tax documents of thousands of the country’s wealthiest people and said his actions “appear to be unparalleled in the I.R.S.’s history.”
content: A former Internal Revenue Service contractor accused of leaking the tax documents of Donald J. Trump and other wealthy Americans was sentenced on Monday to five years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Bennett
title: The Audacity of E. Jean Carroll
description: Her lawsuit against Donald Trump was about defamation. It was also about the worth of a woman, long past middle age, who dared to claim she still had value.
content: Today she’s typically described as a former advice columnist, but that term doesn’t really do justice to E. Jean Carroll’s career pre-Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Rages at U.A.W. President After Biden Endorsement
description: The provocation for the former president’s comments appeared to be remarks that Shawn Fain, the union’s leader, made on Sunday.
content: A few days after the United Auto Workers endorsed President Biden for re-election, former President Donald J. Trump raged at the union’s leader, Shawn Fain, on Sunday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: An Italian Holocaust Survivor Asks if She Has ‘Lived in Vain’
description: Liliana Segre, who has become Italy’s conscience on the Holocaust, says she is pessimistic in the face of rising anti-Semitism.
content: For decades, Liliana Segre visited Italian classrooms to recount her expulsion from school under Benito Mussolini’s anti-Semitic racial laws, her doomed attempt to flee Nazi-controlled Italy, her deportation from Milan’s train station to the death camps of Auschwitz. Her plain-spoken testimony about gas chambers, tattooed arms, casual atrocities and the murders of her father, grandparents and thousands of other Italian Jews made her the conscience and living memory of a country that often prefers not to remember.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: At Penn, Tensions May Only Be Growing After Magill’s Resignation
description: Professors at the University of Pennsylvania have begun to organize, fearing what they view as a plan by the billionaire Marc Rowan to upend academic freedom.
content: Campus protests are not usually aimed at a single person. But last week at the University of Pennsylvania, professors staged a rally targeting Marc Rowan, the New York private-equity billionaire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick, Jonathan Abrams and Nate Schweber
title: Trial in Jam Master Jay’s 2002 Killing Begins in Brooklyn
description: The killing of Jam Master Jay, the Run-DMC D.J., sent shock waves through hip-hop. On Monday, two men went on trial on charges of murdering him.
content: More than 20 years after the hip-hop D.J. Jam Master Jay was gunned down in his Queens recording studio, two men charged in the killing faced a federal jury in Brooklyn on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassandra Vinograd
title: Iran Denies Ordering Drone Strike as Biden Weighs a Response
description: The deaths of three U.S. service members were the first known fatalities from hostile fire since the start of Israel’s war against Hamas.
content: The deaths of three U.S. soldiers in a drone strike in Jordan — the first-known American military fatalities from hostile fire in the widening Middle East crisis — are likely to increase pressure on President Biden, who has tried to limit the American response in order to keep regional tensions from spreading further.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why the L.A. Public Library Acquired a Book Publisher
description: As the library system redefines itself, it has taken the unusual step of bringing in Angel City Press.
content: It’s Monday. Why the Los Angeles Public Library acquired a book publisher. Plus, more on why the editor in chief of The Los Angeles Times resigned this month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher and Amir Hamja
title: At ‘Saltburn’ Party, Bathwater Is an Acquired Taste
description: Devoted fans filled a Brooklyn club for a bash inspired by the film.
content: On Friday night at 3 Dollar Bill, a queer club in the East Williamsburg neighborhood of Brooklyn, partygoers danced and sang along to early 2000s hits by Fergie, Justin Timberlake and, of course, Sophie Ellis-Bextor whose “Murder on the Dancefloor” is currently having a renaissance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: The ABCs of Modern Life, According to Sheila Heti
description: In her new book, the writer presents 10 years of her diaries in an unorthodox arrangement.
content: “No one at this point in history knows how to live, so we read biographies and memoirs, hoping to get some clues,” Sheila Heti writes in “Alphabetical Diaries,” her powerful and intimate new book. That is why we read novels, too, of course — for the clues. Heti knows this. It is why her breakout 2010 novel had an exemplary title, one that could stand in for the title of every real novel from “Don Quixote” down the line: “How Should a Person Be?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A Drone Mix-Up Was Cited in the Deaths of 3 U.S. Troops
description: Also, China’s troubled property giant will be dismantled. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: U.S. air defenses at a remote military outpost in Jordan failed to stop a deadly drone attack yesterday because it arrived at the same time that an American drone was returning to base, American officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Oregon Newspaper to Resume Printing After Embezzlement Forced Layoffs
description: The Eugene Weekly was forced to lay off all 10 of its staff members last month after it discovered tens of thousands of dollars in unpaid bills.
content: A weekly newspaper in Oregon that laid off all of its workers in December after an employee embezzled tens of thousands of dollars will resume its print edition on Feb. 8 after raising enough money through donations, its editor said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Biden Vows to Retaliate, and a Super Bowl Rematch
description: Plus, a new therapy lets an 11-year-old hear for the first time.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Judge Denies Alex Murdaugh’s Request for a New Murder Trial
description: The judge said that a court clerk had made “foolish and fleeting” comments during Mr. Murdaugh’s trial, but that they did not affect the jury’s verdict that he murdered his wife and son.
content: A judge declined on Monday to grant a new trial for Alex Murdaugh, the former South Carolina lawyer convicted of murdering his wife and son, who had argued that he was entitled to a redo because a court clerk had improperly influenced the jurors in his case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: A Climate Change Success Story? Look at Hoboken
description: This flood-prone city on the Hudson River balances climate infrastructure with resident needs.
content: Note: This newsletter was sent to readers in November 2023. Headway is publishing the newsletter as an article to bring them together with other newsletters on site. Read them all here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz, Karen Weise and Mike Isaac
title: Nvidia’s Big Tech Rivals Put Their Own A.I. Chips on the Table
description: Chafing at their dependence, Amazon, Google, Meta and Microsoft are racing to cut into Nvidia’s dominant share of the market.
content: In September, Amazon said it would invest up to $4 billion in Anthropic, a San Francisco start-up working on artificial intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Joni Mitchell Adds a Gig to Her Comeback Tour: The Grammys
description: The Canadian singer-songwriter joins a roster of performers at this Sunday’s awards, including Billie Eilish, Olivia Rodrigo, Travis Scott, U2 and Billy Joel.
content: Nine years ago, Joni Mitchell fans wondered if they might ever hear her perform again, after Mitchell — the Canadian singer-songwriter and icon of the folk movement — had an aneurysm that initially left her unable to speak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: Mix-Up Preceded Deadly Drone Strike in Jordan, U.S. Officials Say
description: The attack on Sunday killed three Army reservists, the first known American military deaths from hostile fire in the turmoil spilling over from Israel’s war with Hamas.
content: Air defenses failed to stop an attack on a U.S. military outpost in Jordan on Sunday that killed three American soldiers at least in part because the hostile drone approached its target at the same time an American drone was returning to the base, two U.S. officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: She Issued a Call to ‘#MakeJewishBabies.’ Some Are Taking It Seriously.
description: Irina Barskaya, a 33-year-old woman in Brooklyn, felt a pull to have children with another Jew after the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks. She’s not the only one.
content: Marrying a Jewish man — and having Jewish children — wasn’t a top priority for Irina Barskaya. Despite pressure from her mother and her older sister, Ms. Barskaya, a 33-year-old hair and makeup artist from Brooklyn, said that in her search for Mr. Right, religion was “never at the forefront.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Do I Dress While I’m Losing Weight?
description: A reader contemplates clothing purchases during a period in which her body is changing.
content: Changes in your body, whether intentional or not, are intrinsically connected to changes in your emotions and sense of self, even before you start taking into account social messaging around weight and physical beauty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Vanderpump Rules’ and the Grammys
description: The Bravo hit returns for an 11th season, and the Recording Academy hands out awards.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Jan. 29-Feb. 4. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: He Stole Dorothy’s Ruby Slippers. He Thought They Had Real Rubies.
description: Terry Martin was spared prison and sentenced instead to one year of supervised release for stealing the slippers from the Judy Garland Museum in Minnesota in 2005.
content: Nearly two decades after he broke into the Judy Garland Museum in Grand Rapids, Minn., and stole a pair of Dorothy’s ruby slippers used in “The Wizard of Oz,” the man who committed the theft has revealed why: He believed the slippers were adorned with real rubies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Amazon Scraps Deal to Buy Maker of Roomba Amid Regulatory Scrutiny
description: Amazon walked away from the $1.7 billion acquisition of iRobot as it faces questions from regulators in the European Union and United States.
content: Amazon said on Monday that it was abandoning plans to buy iRobot, the maker of the self-driving Roomba vacuum, after regulators raised concerns the deal would hurt competition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Voting Is Bewildering This Primary Season. That Worries Experts.
description: New Hampshire’s ballot didn’t include President Biden. South Carolina has two primaries. Nevada has a primary and a caucus. A morass of dates and formats could keep some voters away.
content: Democracy is messy, but usually not this messy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: A Grim LookAt the State of the News
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, January 30, 2024.
content: “Every warning light should be blinking red.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: 17 New Books Coming in February
description: New novels from Tommy Orange and Kristin Hannah; memoirs from Kara Swisher and Leslie Jamison; a biography of Medgar and Myrlie Evers — and more.
content: Spufford’s latest is a speculative historical noir set in a reimagined Jazz Age. The story takes place in Cahokia, a thriving Indigenous metropolis, and follows a detective who gets sucked into an ever-deepening conspiracy as he tries to solve a gruesome murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Weighs a Response to the Drone Strike
description: Plus, Evergrande’s liquidation and Biden’s election strategy.
content: President Biden must decide how far he is willing to go after a drone strike killed three U.S. soldiers at a base in Jordan on Sunday. He vowed to respond to the attack, which he blamed on militant groups backed by Iran, but retaliation could risk a wider war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Georgia Senators Press Biden for Tougher Tariffs on Chinese Solar Panels
description: The issue goes to the core of one of President Biden’s arguments for re-election: that his economic policies are working.
content: A bipartisan quartet of senators, led by two Democrats from the critical swing state of Georgia, are asking President Biden to toughen up tariffs on Chinese solar panels or face a glutted market just as the president’s clean-energy tax credits hit the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset and Danny Hakim
title: The Accusations Against the Atlanta Prosecutor Fani Willis: What We Know
description: Donald Trump’s lawyers want Ms. Willis disqualified from the Georgia election case over accusations that she had a romantic relationship with a subordinate. A judge will decide what happens next.
content: The election interference case against former President Donald J. Trump and 14 of his allies in Georgia has been buffeted by allegations that the main prosecutor, Fani T. Willis, engaged in a romantic relationship with a lawyer she hired to help with the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: Three Days That Changed the Thinking About Black Women’s Health
description: Four decades ago, 2,000 Black women converged on Spelman College for a conference on health.
content: Note: This newsletter was sent to readers in December 2023. Headway is publishing the newsletter as an article to bring it together with other newsletters on site. Read them all here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: The World’s Biggest Jeweler Now Only Sources Recycled Metals
description: Is that as good as it sounds?
content: Pandora, known for its affordable sterling-silver charm bracelets, is the world’s largest jewelry company by volume: The Danish chain sells more than 100 million pieces annually. This week, it announced that it is now sourcing only 100-percent-recycled silver and gold for its collections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: Philips Suspends U.S. Sales of Breathing Machines After Recall
description: Under a settlement with regulators, the company must revamp some operations before resuming sales of its CPAP and ventilator devices in the United States.
content: Philips Respironics announced on Monday that it would halt sales of all of its breathing machines in the United States after reaching a settlement with the Food and Drug Administration over continuing problems with the devices.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: U.S. Charges Iranian Man and Two Canadians in Plot to Kill Refugees
description: Naji Sharifi Zindashti is accused of being the kingpin of a network that targeted defectors and hiring the two Canadians, including a member of the Hells Angels.
content: An Iranian man accused of being the kingpin of a network that targets dissidents has been charged with hiring two Canadians, including a member of the Hells Angels, to kill two Iranian refugees living in Maryland, according to indictments unsealed on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: What if We Don’t Drain the Swamp?
description: A Supreme Court decision last year made it much harder to protect wetlands in the United States.
content: Every child I have ever known is drawn to water — to running creeks and meandering rivers, to buzzing ponds and gently lapping lakes and echoing swamps and cool, mossy fens. Even toddlers who find the ocean overwhelmingly huge and alien will merrily splash in a tidal pool, dabbling their dimpled fingers in the water. To children, a puddle is for stomping. A marshy place is for barefooting, testing the ooze and suck of mud, peering through waving grasses at wild eyes peering back at them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: connoisseurship
description: This word has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word connoisseurship has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 20 in “Dick Wolf, ‘Law & Order’ Creator, Gives 200 Artworks to the Met Museum” by Zachary Small:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Catherine Porter
title: French Farmers Lay ‘Siege’ to Paris in Growing Standoff
description: The authorities warned residents to brace for disruptions as farmers converged on the capital to press a wide range of grievances.
content: Irate farmers deployed tractors to block the main roads in and out of Paris on Monday, in an intensifying standoff that has left the capital girding for disruptions and has become the first major test for France’s newly appointed prime minister, Gabriel Attal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Why Democrats Are Using Personal Abortion Stories
description: Plus: A Taylor Swift endorsement is Biden’s wildest dream.
content: When Dr. Austin Dennard, an OB-GYN in Dallas, learned that her 11-week-old fetus had a fatal medical condition in July 2022, she immediately understood the medical implications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Anat Schwartz and Adam Sella
title: U.N. to Study Reports of Sexual Violence in Israel During Oct. 7 Attack
description: A team from the United Nations has arrived in Israel to examine multiple reports of sexual violence during the Hamas-led attack.
content: A United Nations team has arrived in Israel to examine reports of sexual violence during the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7 even as Hamas and some critics of Israel continue to reject evidence that such assaults occurred.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: They’ll Take the Travis Kelce — Hairdo, That Is
description: Not since Jennifer Aniston has a haircut become so popular. Barbers, in America and abroad, are being inundated with requests for “the Travis Kelce.”
content: Jeffrey Dugas, who cuts hair at Obsidian Barbers in New Brunswick, Canada, has received a very specific request from clients in the past few weeks: They want the same style as Travis Kelce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
title: Details Emerge on U.N. Workers Accused of Aiding Hamas Raid
description: Israeli officials have presented evidence they say ties workers at a Palestinian aid agency in Gaza to violence during the Hamas-led attack on Israel.
content: One is accused of kidnapping a woman. Another is said to have handed out ammunition. A third was described as taking part in the massacre at a kibbutz where 97 people died. And all were said to be employees of the United Nations aid agency that schools, shelters and feeds hundreds of thousands of Palestinians in the Gaza Strip.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Thompson
title: The Lessons of the Crime Wave That Didn’t Happen
description: Fears of violence in the 1980s and ’90s resulted in life sentences for minors that are now being reversed.
content: Note: This newsletter was sent to readers in October 2023. Headway is publishing the newsletter as an article to bring them together with other newsletters on site. Read them all here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia May Jonas
title: Dorm Room Revelations as Microcosms of a Culture
description: In her second novel, “Come and Get It,” Kiley Reid uses chatty college students to make substantive statements about consumerism.
content: Once I realized what Kiley Reid was up to, I started jotting down brand names. Papyrus, Ziploc, Zillow, Ikea, Amy’s, Red Vines, Lubriderm — these are just a smattering of the companies and products mentioned in the first few chapters of Reid’s second novel, “Come and Get It.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: The Results Are In: Here’s What Americans Streamed in 2023
description: Hollywood was on strike for much of the year. And yet the time viewers spent streaming shows and movies went up. A lot.
content: Last year, studios continued to pull back how much they spend on new TV shows. A pair of strikes effectively shut down Hollywood for several months, disrupting new releases of television shows and movies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Monday Briefing
description: Three U.S. service members were killed in Jordan.
content: Three U.S. service members were killed in Jordan yesterday and at least 34 others were injured in what the U.S. said was a drone strike from an Iran-backed militia. The deaths were the first U.S. military fatalities from hostile fire in the turmoil spilling over from Israel’s war with Hamas in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: Evergrande Will Be Dismantled, a ‘Big Bang’ End to Years of Stumbles
description: After multiple delays and even a few faint glimmers of hope, a Hong Kong court has sounded the death knell for what was once China’s biggest real estate firm.
content: Months after China Evergrande ran out of cash and defaulted in 2021, investors around the world scooped up the property developer’s discounted i.o.u.’s, betting that the Chinese government would eventually step in to bail it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: 21 Savage Holds Off Green Day for a Second Week at No. 1
description: The rapper’s latest, “American Dream,” easily outstreamed the veteran pop-punk band’s 14th studio album, “Saviors.”
content: 21 Savage, the London-born Atlanta rapper, easily fended off a challenge from Green Day to hold at No. 1 on the Billboard album chart for a second week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja and Juliet Macur
title: Russian Figure Skater Is Handed Four-Year Ban in Olympic Doping Case
description: Kamila Valieva, once a 15-year-old gold medal favorite, was punished in a case that upended the Beijing Games, and kept other athletes from receiving medals.
content: Kamila Valieva, the teenage Russian figure skater whose positive doping test upended her sport at the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics and kept more than a dozen other athletes from receiving their medals, was banned from competition for four years on Monday by the top court in sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liza Weisstuch
title: Gin and Jellyfish? You Might Be at a Bar in Singapore.
description: Bartenders around the city are mixing up creative cocktails with unexpected, and often ecologically conscious, ingredients. Here are six spots to visit.
content: In the cocktail world, Singapore almost inevitably evokes the pink, gin-based, grenadine-spiked Singapore Sling, a drink born in 1915 at the stylish Long Bar at the Raffles Hotel. In those strait-laced colonial days, it was improper for women to imbibe in public, so a bartender formulated a cocktail that looked like fruit juice. Today, the creative minds at idiosyncratic bars across the city are putting the same spirit of ingenuity to work, driven by eco-consciousness and the island’s diverse heritage, and highlighting some unexpected ingredients. Here are six standout spots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: U.K. to Ban Disposable Vapes in Plan to Combat Use by Children
description: The British government said it would act after surveys showed that the number of young people trying vapes had risen sharply.
content: The brightly colored packaging is a slick mix of ombré pink and lime green. The nicotine inside comes wreathed in a “strawberry kiwi” flavor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: What Evergrande’s Collapse Might Mean for Global Business
description: The long-embattled property developer was finally ordered to liquidate. What comes next will test Western companies’ appetite to keep operating in China.
content: A Hong Kong court on Monday ordered the liquidation of Evergrande, the heavily indebted Chinese property giant. The decision comes two years after the company defaulted, setting off a financial crisis at other developers and adding to the challenges facing the world’s second-largest economy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Jan. 29, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Jan. 29, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper
title: Defense Secretary Returns to Pentagon a Month After Surgery Complications
description: Lloyd J. Austin III was widely criticized for failing to immediately disclose his illness and hospitalization to President Biden and other officials.
content: Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III returned to the Pentagon on Monday for the first time in more than a month, the Defense Department said, after his surgery for prostate cancer and hospitalization for related medical complications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jordyn Holman
title: Walmart Offers Store Managers Company Stock to Make Them Feel Like ‘Owners’
description: The retailer has been raising wages for store workers. It’s now turning its attention to improving salaries and benefits for their bosses.
content: Walmart, the nation’s largest private employer, is raising salaries and benefits for store managers as it looks for ways to retain them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Rosenstrach
title: For ‘Golden Bachelor’ Fans, a Novel About a Golden Baking Contestant
description: In “Mrs. Quinn’s Rise to Fame,” Olivia Ford whips up a sweet confection about a septuagenarian cook with reality TV dreams.
content: On the face of it, 77-year-old Jennifer Quinn lives a life that belongs on “Masterpiece Theater.” She lives in bucolic Kittlesham, an English town that makes you feel as if you’ve “stepped into a secret garden or through the back of a wardrobe,” with “delightfully uneven houses and medieval pubs.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Messages of the E. Jean Carroll Verdict
description: Readers discuss the $83.3 million damages award in her defamation suit against Donald Trump. Also: Advice for Joe Biden; public health; vocational education.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Audiobooks Are Booming. Spotify Wants in on the Action.
description: There are early signs that Spotify’s addition of audiobooks to its streaming service is helping drive audiobook consumption — already a growing market.
content: When Spotify announced last fall that it was adding audiobooks to its streaming service, reactions in the publishing world were mixed: Many publishers saw Spotify’s entrance as an chance to reach new audiences. But some agents and authors worried that streaming could erode the value of audiobooks, a lucrative and growing format.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hisako Ueno and Andrés R. Martínez
title: Toyota Halts Shipments of 10 Models Over Mishandling of Engine Tests
description: A unit of the company used software that made horsepower “values appear smoother.” It’s the second production problem to hit the company in two months.
content: Toyota Motor said it had halted the global shipments of 10 vehicles after it discovered that an affiliate had mishandled the testing of diesel engines used in the automobiles, the latest embarrassing problem to hit the world’s biggest automaker in recent months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.2 Million Homes in California
description: A storybook cottage in Los Angeles, a Prairie-style house in Orange and a renovated 1939 home in Redwood City.
content: This house is in the hills above Laurel Canyon, less than a five-minute drive from Hollywood Boulevard and less than 10 minutes from the nightlife on the Sunset Strip. It is also close to Canyon Country Store, a popular neighborhood market, a Trader Joe’s and the hiking trails in Runyon Canyon Park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson
title: Where Southerners Go to Fill the Tank and Feed the Family
description: Are they gas stations that serve food or restaurants that pump gas? A new photography book explores the lure of these restorative community rest stops.
content: New York City has its bodegas. The South has its gas stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Ben Protess
title: As Trump Awaits Fraud Penalty, a Monitor’s Report Could Raise His Risk
description: A monitor drew attention to “deficiencies” in the Trump Organization’s financial reporting ahead of a verdict in a case brought by New York State that seeks $370 million.
content: As a New York judge weighs Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud case, new accusations of deficiencies in his company’s financial reporting could provide the judge with ammunition for a forceful ruling against the former president and his family business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: How to Turn Your Catan Game Around
description: Klaus Teuber’s fortune-building game requires finely honed negotiation skills, a passing knowledge of probability and, in some cases, card counting.
content: When your journalistic beat consists of providing helpful tips on how to win games, people naturally assume that you are an expert at playing them. That’s not always true, but I like to think that I make up for it with moxie and a reasonably consistent positive attitude.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Princess of Wales Returns Home From Hospital After Abdominal Surgery
description: The sudden hospitalization of Catherine, the wife of Prince William, in mid-January, surprised royal watchers in Britain. She will convalesce for two to three months.
content: Catherine, the Princess of Wales and the wife of Prince William, has returned home from a London hospital almost two weeks after undergoing abdominal surgery, Kensington Palace said in a statement on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: Defense Department Identifies 3 Soldiers Killed at Base in Jordan
description: Officials said the dead were three Army Reserve soldiers from Georgia, part of an engineering company trained for deployment at short notice.
content: The Department of Defense on Monday identified three Army Reserve soldiers who were killed at a U.S. base in Jordan on Sunday in what the Biden administration said was a drone attack from an Iran-backed militia. The department said at least 34 other service members were wounded in the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Superpunchy One-Pan Eggplant Adobo
description: In Kay Chun’s brilliant new recipe, the eggplant stays just firm enough to hold its shape while soaking in those salty-sour adobo flavors.
content: Substituting vegetables in traditionally meat-centric dishes is one of my favorite hacks — whether mushrooms for beef, zucchini for shrimp, or, as in Kay Chun’s new take on Filipino adobo, eggplant for chicken. It’s a brilliant swap: The eggplant stays just firm enough to hold its shape, but gets suffused with the tangy flavors of soy sauce, vinegar and garlic and the softness of coconut milk. Serve it over rice, with a handful of basil leaves or sliced scallions at the end to add a fresh and fragrant rush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt and Lauren Jackson
title: Gaza’s Food Crisis
description: Famine has become a central humanitarian concern in the enclave.
content: Mothers in Gaza are struggling to find clean water and baby formula for their newborns. Families are selling their possessions to buy sacks of flour. Some people are eating animal feed to survive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Vera Klement, Painter Who Saw Both Beauty and Evil, Dies at 93
description: A Holocaust survivor, she once said that she sought in her art to “recognize the nightmare but confirm rather than deny human life.”
content: In late 2009, as she was about to turn 80, Vera Klement was spattering and brushing red paint onto a 6-by-7-foot canvas on the floor of her loft in Chicago where she lived and worked. It depicted a faceless man, his arms pressed tightly to his chest, surrounded by a field of red. To the right, separated by white space, was a black rectangle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Evergrande Must Be Liquidated, a Judge Said. What Happens Next?
description: The giant real estate developer epitomized China’s real estate frenzy, and its downfall fueled the market’s downturn.
content: After nearly two years of false starts, last-ditch proposals and pleas for more time, China Evergrande, an enormous developer, has been ordered to dismantle itself. It’s a big moment. Evergrande’s collapse in 2021 sent China’s housing market into a tailspin. The worries in real estate, where most households put their savings, helped tip the economy into a downturn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller
title: Today’s Teenagers: Anxious About Their Futures and Disillusioned by Politicians
description: More than previous generations, they are concerned about their mental health and educational prospects, new surveys show.
content: Although it has never been easy to be a teenager, the current generation of young Americans feels particularly apprehensive, new polling shows — anxious about their lives, disillusioned about the direction of the country and pessimistic about their futures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Days of Wine and Roses’ Review: Romance on the Rocks
description: Kelli O’Hara and Brian d’Arcy James are superb as a midcentury-modern couple free-falling into addiction in Craig Lucas and Adam Guettel’s musical.
content: Seldom have a pair of alcoholics looked as glamorous as they do in Craig Lucas and Adam Guettel’s bruised romance of a Broadway musical, “Days of Wine and Roses,” starring Kelli O’Hara and Brian d’Arcy James as midcentury-modern Manhattan lovers free-falling all the way to hell, drinks in hand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: After a Slow Start, Sundance Finishes With Plenty of Sales
description: The festival, seen as a barometer for the overall health of the film industry, featured several movies and documentaries snatched up by studios and streaming services.
content: Talk of the demise of the Sundance Film Festival as an incubator for audience-friendly independent films appears to have been greatly exaggerated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Biden’s Options Range From Unsatisfying to Risky After American Deaths
description: President Biden is balancing political pressures, military calculations and regional fragility after a drone strike killed three service members.
content: Even before the drone strike that killed three U.S. service members in Jordan on Sunday, the Biden administration was planning for a moment just like this, debating how it might strike back in ways that would deter Iran’s proxy forces and send a message that Tehran would not miss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Christina Anderson
title: For Europe and NATO, a Russian Invasion Is No Longer Unthinkable
description: Amid crumbling U.S. support for Ukraine and Donald Trump’s rising candidacy, European nations and NATO are making plans to take on Russia by themselves.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia once proclaimed the dissolution of the Soviet empire “the greatest geopolitical catastrophe of the 20th century.” At the time, back in 2005, few expected him to do anything about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Eric Umansky, Eric Krupke, Olivia Natt, Stella Tan, Brendan Klinkenberg, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Rowan Niemisto, Diane Wong, Sophia Lanman, Alyssa Moxley and Chris Wood
title: The Failed Promise of Police Body Cameras
description: The devices were supposed to be a revolution in accountability. What went wrong?
content: Warning: This episode contains strong language and audio excerpts of violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: The Smile Gets Wonderfully Stranger
description: A spinoff of Radiohead, the trio of Jonny Greenwood, Tom Skinner and Thom Yorke pushes further from the solid ground of pop on its second studio LP, “Wall of Eyes.”
content: “Don’t think you know me,” Thom Yorke intones near the end of the Smile’s second studio album, “Wall of Eyes.” He adds, “Don’t think that I am everything you say.” With its new LP, the Smile makes itself increasingly elusive. It’s now a band intent on destabilizing structures and dissolving expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, Kate Christobek and Liset Cruz
title: In Court, N.R.A. Questions Its Longtime Chief About His Luxury Spending
description: Wayne LaPierre was grilled by lawyers from a legal team he hired in testimony meant to show that the gun group has mended its ways.
content: On Monday, Wayne LaPierre faced a second day of grilling on the witness stand about his lavish spending as the longtime chief of the National Rifle Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Supreme Court’s Mixed Record on Adhering to Precedent
description: The current court is not out of step with earlier ones in how often it overturns decisions. But it is more apt to do so to reach conservative results.
content: It can sometimes seem that the Supreme Court is on a jurisprudential rampage that has left the legal landscape cluttered with the corpses of discarded precedents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Hottest Job in Corporate America? The Executive in Charge of A.I.
description: Many feared that artificial intelligence would kill jobs. But hospitals, insurance companies and others are creating roles to navigate and harness the disruptive technology.
content: In September, the Mayo Clinic in Arizona created a first-of-its-kind job at the hospital system: chief artificial intelligence officer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘The Greatest Night in Pop’ Review: They Were the World
description: This documentary shows the highlights of the recording session for the charity song “We Are the World,” which assembled a who’s who of pop celebrities.
content: In late 1984 the singer and activist Harry Belafonte was both impressed and perturbed by “Do They Know It’s Christmas?,” a British charity single featuring a cast of pop stars. The proceeds from the project went to Ethiopian famine relief. Belafonte complained to the music manager Ken Kragen, “We have white folks saving Black folks and we don’t have Black folks saving Black folks.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: A ‘Substantial’ Atmospheric River Will Soak the West Coast This Week
description: Extreme rainfall and heavy snow is (again) forecast across the West.
content: Another atmospheric river will arrive in the northwestern United States on Tuesday, bringing excessive rain and mountain snow down the entire West Coast as it drifts south through Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: How to Set the Menu for a Special Food Project
description: The Food team’s interactive on restaurant menus has roots in an earlier effort.
content: Tanya Sichynsky likes to collect restaurant menus, and she even has a few of them framed on the walls of her apartment in New York. The menus she displays represent a few of the dinners she had during meaningful moments in her life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Whipple
title: How Biden Beats Trump
description: The president has a strong populist case to make for a future in which ordinary Americans, and the ideals embodied in our Constitution, can prosper.
content: For months, battered by President Biden’s dismal 2024 re-election polls, Democrats have been undergoing a kind of collective nervous breakdown over Mr. Biden’s re-election prospects against Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: GoFundMe Is a Boon for Disaster Survivors. Especially the Wealthy Ones.
description: Campaigns on the crowdfunding site raised more money for wildfire survivors with high incomes than for those who need help most, researchers found.
content: As climate-fueled disasters destroy more American homes, the crowdfunding platform GoFundMe has exploded in popularity. Its appeal is simple: People can provide cash directly to survivors, which is quicker than insurance and often more generous than government aid.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: What Might E. Jean Carroll Do With $83 Million?
description: A jury awarded Ms. Carroll a huge payout. She would like to do “something good” with it.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday, and we’ll look at the $83.3 million verdict in the defamation case against Donald Trump. We’ll also get details on the fallout from a traffic stop in Harlem involving a member of the City Council.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Are Edibles Safer Than Smoking?
description: The health risks of cannabis depend in part on how you use the drug.
content: Cannabis-infused chocolate fountains are flowing at weddings. “Budtenders” are pouring cannabis cocktails. And as sales of edibles are trending up, cannabis brands are emphasizing the idea that the products might offer a healthier alternative to bongs or blunts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Promises and Problems of Buying Local
description: There’s no right answer to whether buying local is better. It’s a matter, instead, of trade-offs.
content: You can crisscross North Dakota from Fargo to Bismarck to Minot and never see a Walgreens, Rite-Aid or Walmart pharmacy. With narrow exceptions, a 1963 state law prohibits drugstores that aren’t majority-owned by a pharmacist. (CVS Health, whose predecessor company was already in the state in 1963, is grandfathered in.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
title: U.N. Agency for Palestinians Imperiled by Terrorism Charges
description: Donors have pulled funds for the main aid agency in Gaza after allegations that some employees took part in the Oct. 7 attack, but it is not clear who would fill the vacuum if it ran out of money.
content: Leaders of the largest United Nations agency in Gaza warned on Monday that it may soon run out of money as new allegations emerged about Hamas’s influence on the organization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Motyka
title: N. Scott Momaday, Pulitzer-Winning Native American Novelist, Dies at 89
description: The success of his novel “House Made of Dawn,” the first work by a Native American to win a Pulitzer, inspired a wave of Native literature.
content: N. Scott Momaday, whose portrayal of a disaffected World War II veteran’s journey to spiritual renewal in his novel “House Made of Dawn” won a Pulitzer Prize, the first for a Native American author, heralding a more prominent place in contemporary literature for Native writers, died on Wednesday at his home in Sante Fe, N.M. He was 89.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Have Your Drinking Habits Changed in Recent Years?
description: The Times wants to hear from you.
content: Dry January is trickling to a close, marking the end of a month when many people rethink their relationship with drinking.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman
title: As Buses of Migrants Arrive in Chicago Suburbs, Residents Debate the Role of Their Towns
description: In recent weeks, buses have been bypassing the city for its smaller outlying communities, where people are unaccustomed to the flow of newcomers.
content: In different times, the tiny brick Metra station in the town of Wilmette in suburban Chicago was just a place where commuters grabbed lattes and waited on black metal benches before boarding trains to the city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What Is Your Experience With Group Chats?
description: Tell us how never-ending digital conversations affect you.
content: Are you constantly texting? How much of your time do you spend in group chats? How would you describe the role those chats play in your life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen and Vjosa Isai
title: Former N.H.L. Player Faces Sexual Assault Charges in Canada
description: The accusation, made in London, Ontario, in 2018, has put the country’s hockey organization into turmoil and outraged the public.
content: A former National Hockey League player has been charged in Canada with sexual assault, his lawyer has confirmed, the latest development in a case that has brought turmoil to the sport’s Canadian governing body and angered many people across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Nikki Haley Can Do a Lot of Damage
description: Hounding Trump is an important task.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. It’s fair to say that Nikki Haley has next to no chance of beating Donald Trump for the Republican nomination. Give her your best advice: Give up now? Fight a guerrilla campaign right up to the G.O.P. convention? Or join forces with someone like Joe Manchin in a third party?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: King Charles Released From Hospital After Prostate Procedure
description: Charles was released on Monday hours after Catherine, Princess of Wales, left the same hospital following abdominal surgery.
content: King Charles III was released from a London hospital on Monday after undergoing a procedure to treat an enlarged prostate, Buckingham Palace officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: Hate Crimes Reported in Schools Nearly Doubled Between 2018 and 2022
description: Black students were the most frequent reported victims, followed by L.G.B.T.Q. and Jewish students, according to F.B.I. statistics.
content: The number of reported hate crimes in schools and colleges nearly doubled between 2018 and 2022, according to data released Monday by the F.B.I.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: In the Race to Replace George Santos, National Issues Reverberate
description: Here’s what you need to know about the special House election on Feb. 13, pitting former Representative Tom Suozzi, a Democrat, against the Republican Party’s candidate, Mazi Pilip, a local legislator.
content: The Israel-Hamas war. Abortion rights. Immigration policy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Teen Drug and Alcohol Use Linked to Mental Health Distress
description: Substance use by adolescents may prove valuable in identifying the presence of underlying disorders, a new study suggests.
content: Teenagers who use cannabis, alcohol and nicotine are more likely to have underlying psychiatric symptoms, and worse symptoms, than their peers who are not regularly using substances, new research has found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Illinois Hearing Officer, Ex-G.O.P. Judge, Says Trump Engaged in Insurrection
description: But the hearing officer said the State Board of Elections should let the courts decide whether Mr. Trump’s conduct disqualified him from the ballot.
content: A former Republican judge appointed to hear arguments on whether to disqualify former President Donald J. Trump from the Illinois primary ballot said on Sunday that he believed Mr. Trump engaged in insurrection by attempting to remain in office after the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Ziegler
title: How Trump Could Institute a Backdoor Federal Abortion Ban
description: President Biden should be clear about the risks of a second Trump term.
content: For many Americans who support abortion rights, the election in November will most likely come down to a choice between voting for President Biden and staying home. They won’t vote for the man who ensured Roe v. Wade’s demise, but many of them are unenthusiastic about the prospect of Mr. Biden being the Democratic nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Gaia Pianigiani
title: Contested Migrant Deal Between Albania and Italy Moves Forward
description: A court ruled that an accord for Italy to send asylum seekers to Albania while their cases are heard was constitutional, moving it closer to taking effect.
content: An Albanian court on Monday gave the green light to an agreement allowing Italy to send migrants who are rescued in the Mediterranean by Italian ships to detention centers in Albania while their asylum claims are considered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Skip the Flowers for a Sweethearts Cake From Nick Morgenstern
description: Sip coffee and listen to Bach’s “Coffee Cantata,” watch a chocolate maker documentary with an accompanying tasting and more food news.
content: A dozen roses would be challenged to compete with the delectable Sweethearts Cake from Nick Morgenstern, the ice cream wizard. A raspberry-dusted slather of gossamer whipped cream covers a half-cylinder of Madagascar vanilla ice cream, set on raspberry sponge cake for a snowy, edible Quonset hut. Hearts of tart red fruit jam show up in each slice to punctuate the delicate sweetness. It serves four, but just two might make short work of it. Though this confection needs no embellishment, a few spoonfuls alongside the raspberry coulis, a new intense sauce from Francine’s Outrageous Kitchen, puts it on a pedestal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron
title: When the Governor Shotguns a Beer (or Maybe a Spiked Iced Tea)
description: The moment with Gov. Wes Moore of Maryland on Sunday garnered the approval of sports fans, but it didn’t ultimately help the Baltimore Ravens.
content: It is an adage in politics that voters want to elect politicians they can see themselves sharing a beer with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darian Symoné Harvin and Caitie Kelly
title: How to Wash Your Hair
description: A guide to building an effective, adaptable routine for every hair type.
content: Don’t I know how to do this already? you might be asking. But while washing your hair might seem straightforward, a truly effective cleanse requires some thought and expertise. Just like the skin on our faces, each person’s scalp, and the hair that grows out of it, is different. Using the wrong products for your hair type can lead to oily roots, flaky skin and lackluster strands. What’s more, our hair’s needs can shift daily, so the best routine is one that’s both personalized and flexible. Here’s how to tailor your approach to achieve clean, healthy tresses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Lisa Lerer, Katie Glueck and Katie Rogers
title: Inside Biden’s Anti-Trump Battle Plan (and Where Taylor Swift Fits In)
description: Watching Donald Trump ascend, the newly energized Biden campaign is aiming to make the general election all about him. It’s also hoping for some big endorsements.
content: As former President Donald J. Trump speeds toward the Republican nomination, President Biden is moving quickly to pump energy into his re-election bid, kicking off what is likely to be an ugly, dispiriting and historically long slog to November between two unpopular nominees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel and John Eligon
title: African National Congress Suspends Former President Jacob Zuma
description: After defending the former South African president and party leader during a slew of corruption scandals, the country’s powerful governing party punished him for endorsing the opposition.
content: South Africa’s governing party, the African National Congress, in a remarkable rebuke, suspended its former president, Jacob Zuma, on Monday, for launching “vitriolic attacks” against the organization after throwing his support behind a rival political party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Short Stories That Became Major Films?
description: Certain brief literary works have more than filled the big screen over the years. See how many stories and films you recognize in this quick quiz.
content: Certain brief literary works have more than filled the big screen over the years. See how many stories and films you recognize in this quick quiz.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Williamsburg. What Happened?
description: How the Brooklyn neighborhood moved from bohemian haven to luxury shopping destination.
content: How the Brooklyn neighborhood moved from bohemian haven to luxury shopping destination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Balakrishnan Rajagopal
title: Domicide: The Mass Destruction of Homes Should Be a Crime Against Humanity
description: What has happened to homes and lives in Gaza is a stand-alone crime. Even if it is physically rebuilt, the trauma of losing homes will last for decades.
content: What has happened to homes and lives in Gaza is a stand-alone crime. Even if it is physically rebuilt, the trauma of losing homes will last for decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chevaz Clarke
title: French Farmers Block Roads Around Paris, Escalating Protests
description: Farmers around France sought to put pressure on the government over a wide range of grievances concerning the future of their industry.
content: Farmers around France sought to put pressure on the government over a wide range of grievances concerning the future of their industry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Heavy Rain and Cold Worsen Conditions for Palestinians in Gaza
description: Days of torrential rains have exacerbated the dire humanitarian crisis in Gaza, where tens of thousands of people are displaced.
content: Days of torrential rains have exacerbated the dire humanitarian crisis in Gaza, where tens of thousands of people are displaced.
source.name: The New York Times
